<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>

Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of callback:
```c
static ssize_t
callback (void *cls,
          uint64_t pos,
          char *buf,
          size_t buf_size)
{
  size_t size_to_copy;
  struct ResponseContentCallbackParam *const param =
    (struct ResponseContentCallbackParam *) cls;

  /* Note: 'pos' will never exceed size of transmitted data. */
  /* You can use 'pos == param->response_size' in next check. */
  if (pos >= param->response_size)
  {   /* Whole response was sent. Signal end of response. */
    return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM;
  }

  /* Pseudo code.        *
  if (data_not_ready)
    {
      // Callback will be called again on next loop.
      // Consider suspending connection until data will be ready.
      return 0;
    }
   * End of pseudo code. */
  if (buf_size < (param->response_size - pos))
    size_to_copy = buf_size;
  else
    size_to_copy = (size_t) (param->response_size - pos);

  memcpy (buf, param->response_data + pos, size_to_copy);

  /* Pseudo code.        *
  if (error_preparing_response)
    {
      // Close connection with error.
      return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR;
    }
   * End of pseudo code. */
  /* Return amount of data copied to buffer. */
  /* The 'buf_size' is always smaller than SSIZE_MAX therefore it's safe
   * to cast 'size_to_copy' to 'ssize_t'. */
  /* assert (size_to_copy <= buf_size); */
  return (ssize_t) size_to_copy;
}
```

explanation: Only actual controlling expressions in the compiled code need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. The two if-statements above are the only controlling constructs in this function and therefore must be checked to ensure their controlling expressions are not invariant. The pseudo-code if-blocks in the comments are not compiled and thus are not subject to MISRA enforcement here. There are no loops (for/while/do-while) or switch statements in the function that would create additional controlling expressions to review. Other statements (memcpy, return cast, local variable declarations and comments) are not controlling expressions and do not pertain to Rule 14.3, so they do not require investigation under this rule.
